India's health indicators have improved in recent times but continue to lag behind those of its peer nations.
The country has an estimated active health workers’ density much lower than the WHO recommended thresholds [1].

The paucity of skilled personnel is a multi-factorial issue and needs to be addressed if India is to accelerate its progress toward achieving universal health coverage and its sustainable development goals (SDGs).
The issue is compounded by the skewed inter-state, urban-rural, and public-private sector divide.
The authors describe these issues by providing an overview of the public and private sectors and the growing divide between them due to their divergent strategies.

The recommendations made to address the paucity of quality health personnel include the creation of transparent governance, strengthening the health infrastructure, upskilling the existing workforce, and creating partnerships with the much larger private sector.

The methodology used is the READ approach [3], which is a systematic approach for document analysis in health policy research, consisting of readying one's materials, extracting the data, and analyzing it to distill the findings.
The literature search resulted in the selection and analysis of 56 articles.
The 56 articles were published in peer-reviewed journals.
The selected articles were published between 2005 and 2021.
The corresponding authors' experiential knowledge served as the foundation for the analysis of the selected articles.

The government-funded health sector is a part of the public health sector and is responsible for providing healthcare to vulnerable populations. It has been chronically underfunded with only 1.28% of the GDP.
India has 0.7 public hospital beds per 100,000 people and 0.576 physicians per 1,000 population in 2000, compared to the World Health Organization's recommended doctor-to-population ratio of 1:1,000.
Since the inception of the National Health Mission (NHM) in 2005, the government aimed to increase the quantum of services provided in the public health sector.
Only 37% of the population had any health insurance coverage in 2018, indicating a lack of widespread coverage in the public health sector.
The for-profit private health sector has become the dominant provider of healthcare and is perceived to provide quality care. It consumes 5.1% of the GDP, financed by Out-Of-Pocket (OOP) expenditure.
Narayana Health is an example of a world-class health facility in the private health sector, known for providing internationally accredited, high-quality, tertiary healthcare services.

The private health sector spans a wide range, from world-class health facilities to individual informal provider clinics, which are manned by solo providers without formal medical qualifications or registrations.
The government-funded health sector, despite aiming to increase the quantum of services provided, has a lack of focus on quality, which has failed to make a dent in healthcare indicators.
